**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19**, and **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because the Defendant transacts business and owns property in Lynn, within Essex County, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred therein.

**Mass. R. Civ. P. 3**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to **Mass. R. Civ. P. 3** and **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to **Mass. R. Civ. P. 3** and **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.raw_text: Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.00 et seq.)
Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain a functioning smoke detector created an unreasonably dangerous condition in violation of the Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.00 et seq.) and applicable housing safety requirements.

See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a legal duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining common areas and safety devices in the Premises, including ensuring that hallways were equipped with properly functioning smoke detectors in compliance with governing statutes and codes. See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landlord owes duty of reasonable care to lawful occupants); **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) (landlord’s duty of reasonable care applies to common areas).
See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan discussing the abandonment of licensee/invitee distinctions and questioning the treatment of trespassers. It does not address landlord-tenant relationships, common areas, or safety devices such as smoke detectors, nor does it expressly state that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful occupants. While the main Mounsey opinion is often cited for a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers to lawful visitors, that rule is not evident in the quoted passage, so this specific text does not support the detailed proposition claimed.
See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a legal duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining common areas and safety devices in the Premises, including ensuring that hallways were equipped with properly functioning smoke detectors in compliance with governing statutes and codes. See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landlord owes duty of reasonable care to lawful occupants); **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) (landlord’s duty of reasonable care applies to common areas).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki does stand for the broader rule that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in negligence, but its specific holding concerns negligent maintenance of a porch railing on the *demised premises*, not common areas or safety devices like smoke detectors. The opinion discusses prior cases (Lindsey, King) as establishing the landlord’s duty of reasonable care in common passageways, but Young itself is cited there only for extending the duty to areas rented to the tenant. Thus, using Young v. Garwacki for the proposition that the landlord’s duty of reasonable care applies to common areas (such as hallways with smoke detectors) is inaccurate; that point is supported by Lindsey and King, not by Young itself.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.relevant_excerpt: “In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra. We said that ‘the status of the person visited, landowner or lessee, should not affect the visitor’s right to personal safety or the landowner’s obligation reasonably to maintain premises in his control.’ Id. at 82. In King v. G & M Realty Corp., supra, we extended the landlord’s general and continuing duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of common passageways to include tenants as well as their visitors.”

**G.L. c. 143, \u00a7\u00a7 3\u20134**.proposition: Defendant’s duty arises under both common law and applicable statutes and regulations, including **G.L. c. 143, §§ 3–4**, the **Massachusetts State Building Code (780 CMR)**, and the **State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.00)**, which collectively require that smoke detection systems in multi-unit residences be properly installed, maintained, and operable.

**Massachusetts State Building Code (780.proposition: Defendant’s duty arises under both common law and applicable statutes and regulations, including **G.L. c. 143, §§ 3–4**, the **Massachusetts State Building Code (780 CMR)**, and the **State Fire Code (527 CMR 1.00)**, which collectively require that smoke detection systems in multi-unit residences be properly installed, maintained, and operable.

See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App.raw_text: See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 751 (2005)
See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App.proposition: Defendant’s omissions and negligence directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, losses, and damages. See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 751 (2005) (landlord liable for failure to maintain safe premises after notice of defect).
See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Jablonski v. Casey as authority that a landlord is liable, on negligence/omission grounds, for failure to maintain safe premises after notice of a defect. In this decision, the court affirms findings that the landlord promptly repaired conditions after notice, that there was no breach of the warranty of habitability, no breach of quiet enjoyment, and thus no liability. The case therefore does not support a proposition about landlord liability for omissions causing the tenant’s injuries; it is instead an example where such liability was rejected on the facts.
See **Jablonski v. Casey**, 64 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. While these conditions were documented by the board of health pursuant to an inspection, a reinspection less than two weeks later indicated that substantially all the conditions had been satisfactorily addressed. The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph,.raw_text: See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph,.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff was foreseeable and of the kind likely to result from Defendant’s negligent maintenance of fire safety equipment. See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996) (foreseeability defines scope of duty).
See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurring excerpt indicates the opposite of the claimed proposition. Justice Lynch agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence, which undermines the assertion that the harm was foreseeable and of the kind likely to result. While the case certainly discusses foreseeability and scope of duty, this passage does not support the specific proposition that the harm here was foreseeable; it refutes it.
See **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Sto.raw_text: See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Sto.proposition: The breach of Defendant’s statutory and regulatory obligations constitutes evidence of negligence. See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (statutory violation as evidence of negligence); **Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 401, 406 (1991).
See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Sto.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Sto.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 on civil liability and states that such a statutory violation is not negligence per se but is only “some evidence” of negligence. That aligns with the proposition that breach of statutory and regulatory obligations constitutes evidence of negligence, not automatic liability. Thus Bennett is accurately cited as authority for the proposition that a statutory violation is evidence of negligence under Massachusetts law.
See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Sto.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.proposition: The breach of Defendant’s statutory and regulatory obligations constitutes evidence of negligence. See **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (statutory violation as evidence of negligence); **Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 401, 406 (1991).
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: Ulwick expressly rejects statutory violations as an independent basis for civil liability and reiterates that in Massachusetts a statutory violation is not negligence per se. The court quotes Bennett for the principle that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty and holds that, because no common-law duty exists on these facts, the alleged statutory violations cannot create tort liability. Thus, Ulwick does not stand for the broader proposition that breach of statutory and regulatory obligations constitutes evidence of negligence in this context; it limits, rather than expands, that idea.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "Violations of these statutes invoke criminal penalties, but the statutes do not expressly or implicitly grant an independent ground for civil liability.... 'It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se.' Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358-359 (1990). Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

See **Miller v. Federated Dep\u2019t Sto.raw_text: See **Miller v. Federated Dep’t Stores, Inc.**, 364 Mass. 340, 343–44 (1973)
See **Miller v. Federated Dep\u2019t Sto.proposition: Plaintiff, exercising due care for her own safety, was injured as a direct result of Defendant’s negligence. See **Miller v. Federated Dep’t Stores, Inc.**, 364 Mass. 340, 343–44 (1973) (landlord liability for negligent maintenance of safety devices); **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368, 376 (2010).
See **Miller v. Federated Dep\u2019t Sto.case_name: Miller v. Federated Department Stores, Inc.
See **Miller v. Federated Dep\u2019t Sto.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a plaintiff injured as a direct result of a defendant’s negligence, specifically landlord liability for negligent maintenance of safety devices. Miller, however, is a respondeat superior / scope-of-employment case about an employer’s vicarious liability for an employee’s intentional assault on a customer. The court does not analyze negligence, landlord duties, or maintenance of safety devices; it ultimately holds the employer is not liable because the assault was outside the scope of employment. Thus it does not support the cited negligence/landlord-liability proposition.
See **Miller v. Federated Dep\u2019t Sto.relevant_excerpt: “We now come to the central issue in this case, whether the jury, on the basis of all the evidence most favorable to the plaintiffs, rationally could have found that Melnick was acting within the scope of his employment when he struck Mrs. Miller. An evaluation of all the evidence, including Melnick’s testimony, leads us to conclude that such a finding was not warranted and, therefore, that Federated was entitled to directed verdicts on counts 1 and 3.”

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff, exercising due care for her own safety, was injured as a direct result of Defendant’s negligence. See **Miller v. Federated Dep’t Stores, Inc.**, 364 Mass. 340, 343–44 (1973) (landlord liability for negligent maintenance of safety devices); **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368, 376 (2010).
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos deals with premises liability for snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, applying a general reasonable-care standard to property owners. It does not discuss or articulate the elements that the plaintiff was ‘exercising due care’ or that he was ‘injured as a direct result of defendant’s negligence’ in the sense of setting out that specific causation/due-care formulation. The decision is about the scope of a landowner’s duty, not about the particular negligence/due care elements referenced in the proposition, so it does not support that proposition directly.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

**Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated Plaintiff’s right to safe and habitable premises under the **implied warranty of habitability**, as recognized in **Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973), further evidencing the negligent failure to maintain habitability standards.
**Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363.support_reasoning: The opinion (a concurrence/dissent) clearly recognizes that Massachusetts should abandon caveat emptor and impose on landlords an implied obligation to provide habitable premises, tied at least to statutory and code-based minimum standards. While the concurring justice disagrees with the majority’s broader formulation of an implied warranty of habitability, he expressly endorses an implied agreement that premises comply with mandatory habitability standards and that this obligation is interdependent with the tenant’s duty to pay rent. Thus, the case supports citing Hemingway for the existence of an implied warranty/obligation of habitability and landlord liability for failure to maintain habitability, though the precise contours are debated within the opinion.
**Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway**, 363.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

See **Griffiths v. Campbell**, 425 Mass..proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered serious personal injuries, medical expenses, wage loss, property damage, pain and suffering, and emotional distress, all to her detriment. See **Griffiths v. Campbell**, 425 Mass. 31, 33 (1997) (damages recoverable for personal injury and economic loss resulting from negligence).
See **Griffiths v. Campbell**, 425 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns landlord liability for the wrongful death of a police officer and turns entirely on foreseeability and proximate cause, not on the categories of damages recoverable in a negligence action. The court ultimately holds that the evidence was insufficient to impose liability and orders judgment for the defendants; it does not discuss or endorse any general rule that damages are recoverable for personal injuries, economic loss, or related harms resulting from negligence. Using this case as authority for the broad damages proposition is therefore inaccurate.
See **Griffiths v. Campbell**, 425 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that the evidence was insufficient to warrant the imposition of liability. The defendants' motions for judgment n.o.v. should have been allowed.… Even if Campbell had known that drugs were being sold out of the apartment building and was negligent in not reporting that fact to the police, it was not an omission foreseeable that a police officer would be murdered while conducting a drug raid."

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: B. Award her reasonable costs of suit and pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
